Table 2 Sample Mn4+/ Mntotal (%) Mn3+/ Mntotal (%) Mn2+/ Mntotal (%) Oβ/Ototal (%) Mn-AC 34.55 45.09 20.36 59.10 Mn-SH 25.63 60.89 13.58 42.65 Mn-AH 24.60 58.33 17.07 38.49 A comparison of bifunctional MnO x catalysts prepared via different precipitants for simultaneous removal NO and CO Xiaodi Li Yanhua Jiang Shan Ren ⁎ Zhichao Chen Mingming Wang Jiangling Li Jian Yang Hongsheng Chen ⁎ College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In this work, ammonium carbonate, sodium hydroxide, and ammonium hydroxide were selected as the precipitants to prepare bifunctional MnO x catalysts via the PEG-assisted co-precipitation method. SEM analysis revealed that MnO x catalysts prepared with ammonium carbonate (AC) displayed a spherical morphology with relatively large size, whereas the catalysts synthesized with sodium hydroxide (SH) and ammonium hydroxide (AH) exhibited polyhedron shapes with smaller size. The results demonstrated that Mn-AC catalyst presented superior catalytic activity for both NO reduction and CO oxidation, achieving 89% NO conversion at 100 ºC and over 80% CO conversion at 200 ºC, outperforming Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts. Mn-AC catalyst possessed more abundant Mn4+ species and surface chemisorbed oxygen than Mn-AH and Mn-SH catalysts, which served as a significant motivation for the difference in catalytic activity. Additionally, Mn-AC catalyst exhibited stronger surface acidity, which facilitated the adsorption and activation of ammonia species in the NH3-SCR reaction. Furthermore, in situ DRIFTS experiment suggested that the pre-desorption of CO promoted the adsorption and activation of NO. On this basis, the possible mechanism model of three precipitants on bifunctional MnO x catalysts was proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bifunctional MnOx catalyst Precipitants Simultaneous removal NO reduction CO oxidation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Recently, the emission of various pollutants from the industrial flue gas, including nitrogen oxides (NO x ), sulfur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and carbon monoxide (CO), has emerged as an increasingly urgent global environmental concern [1,2]. Although significant progress has been made in controlling SO2 and particulates emissions, the decrease of NO x and CO emissions remains a crucial factor in improving air quality [3,4]. Selective catalytic reduction of NO x using ammonia (NH3-SCR) is currently recognized as the most efficient and commonly employed technology for removing NO x [5–7]. Furthermore, the secondary combustion of CO in the flue gas using the flue gas recirculation (FGR) has proven to be ineffective for reducing low-concentration CO emission [8]. However, CO catalytic oxidation was regarded as a highly promising technology for eliminating low-concentration CO due to its excellent catalytic performance, garnering significant attention in various industrial fields [9,10]. Importantly, it should be noted that CO catalytic oxidation is an exothermic process [11], and can potentially serve as an excellent heat resource for SCR catalysts. Therefore, utilizing the SCR catalyst for CO catalytic oxidation during the denitration process is feasible. Manganese oxide (MnO x ) has gained widespread attention due to its exceptional redox properties stemming from electron migration within its d shell. The unique characteristic of MnO x made it a valuable material with a diverse range of applications, including energy, environment, and catalysis [12–15]. However, despite its immense potential, the practical application of pristine MnO x as catalyst was still impeded by certain limitations, such as inadequate thermal stability and low specific surface area [16,17]. In response to these challenges, massive efforts have been undertaken by some researchers to improve the catalytic efficiency of MnO x catalysts [18,19]. It was widely recognized that the preparation method had significant effects on the structure, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of MnO x catalysts [20]. To date, various methods, including sol-gel, precipitation, and hydrothermal methods, have been extensively utilized for the synthesis of manganese oxide catalysts [21,22]. Among these methods, the conventional precipitation method was extensively employed because of its favorable operability and wide applicability [17]. Previous studies reported that the choice of precipitant had a considerable influence on the crystalline phase of MnO x catalyst [23,24]. For instance, Cai et al. [24] prepared CuMnO x catalyst by the co-precipitation method with different precipitants for CO catalytic oxidation, and found that Na2CO3 as precipitant could generate the catalyst composing of Mn2O3 and CuO, with a large specific area and excellent CO catalytic activity. Similarly, Chen et al. [18] explored the effect of precipitant on the MnFeO x catalyst for NH3-SCR reaction. The result showed that the anions of the precipitant played a significant role in determining the formation of catalytic phase, which subsequently affected the catalytic activity of the catalyst. However, the relationship between the precipitants and the catalytic activity of bifunctional MnO x catalysts that simultaneously eliminate NO x and CO remains unclear. Given the aforementioned reasons, it is of great significance to explore the influence of different precipitants on the bifunctional MnO x catalysts during the precipitation process. Herein, bifunctional MnO x catalysts were prepared using ammonium carbonate, sodium hydroxide, and ammonium hydroxide as precipitants. The catalytic performance of the obtained catalysts was comprehensively assessed by conducting SCR catalytic activity and CO oxidation performance tests. Furthermore, the structure and physicochemical properties of bifunctional MnO x catalysts were thoroughly characterized, and the key factors that governing the catalytic activity of bifunctional MnO x catalysts for simultaneous removing NO x and CO were elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and characterization of catalysts The bifunctional MnO x catalysts were synthesized using the PEG-assisted co-precipitation method, employing three different precipitants. The resulting samples were labeled as Mn-X catalysts, where X represented the specific precipitant used (AC, SH or AH). Detailed synthesis procedure and characterization techniques could be found in the Supporting Information (SI). 2.2 Catalytic performance measurements The catalytic performance of catalysts were evaluated using a fixed-ded quartz reactor with an internal diameter of 7 mm. The reaction atmosphere comprised specific gas mixtures depending on the concrete experiment condition. For the separate SCR experiment, the gas mixture contained 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 11% O2, and N2 as balance gas. For the separate CO catalytic oxidation experiment, the gas mixture comprised 1000 ppm CO, 11% O2, and N2 as balance gas. The coordinate experiment employed a gas mixture with 500 ppm NO, 1000 ppm CO, 500 ppm NH3, 11% O2, and N2 as balance gas. All experiments were performed at a total gas rate of 300 mL·min−1, corresponding to a fixed gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 90,000 h − 1. Furthermore, to explore the catalytic performance under different GHSV conditions, additional experiments were conducted with fixed GHSV of 90,000 h − 1, 100,000 h − 1 and 120,000 h − 1, respectively. A FTIR spectrometer (Antaris IGS, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was employed to continuously monitor the concentrations of NO, CO, NO2, N2O and NH3. The NO conversion rate, CO removal efficiency, and N2 selectivity were calculated using Eqs. (1)-(3): (1) NO conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in ) × 100 (2) CO conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in ) × 100 (3) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( [ NO x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ NO x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ NO x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out ) × 100 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural characterization XRD analysis was employed to identify the phase composition and crystallinity of bifunctional MnO x catalysts synthesized using different precipitants, as shown in Fig. 1 . Compared with XRD patterns of standard MnO2 (PDF 44–0141), Mn3O4 (PDF 24–0734 and PDF 80–0382), and Mn5O8 (PDF 39–1218) samples, Mn-AC catalyst exhibited a combination of diffraction peaks corresponding to MnO2 (PDF 44–0141) and Mn3O4 (PDF 24–0734), while Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts displayed the mixed diffraction phases of Mn3O4 (PDF 80–0382) and Mn5O8 (PDF 39–1218). Previous literatures reported that manganese oxides with higher valence state were advantageous for facilitating NO reduction and CO oxidation, with catalytic activity following the trend of MnO2 > Mn2O3 > Mn5O8 > Mn3O4 [25,26]. Interestingly, Mn-AC catalyst, which contained the diffraction phase of MnO2, displayed excellent catalytic activity for both NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation. This result implied that the presence of MnO2 might play a crucial role in enhancing the catalytic activity of Mn-AC catalyst. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 2 . According to the IUPAC classification, it could be seen that all catalysts exhibited the typical IV type isotherms, as depicted in Fig. 2(a). Mn-AC catalyst exhibited the H1 type hysteresis loop, while Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts displayed the H3 type hysteresis loop within the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.4 to 1.0, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure in all samples [27]. Fig. 2(b) showed the pore size distribution as calculated by the BJH method from the desorption branch of the nitrogen isotherms. Notably, all catalysts showed distinct variations in pore sizes, as a result of the different precipitants. The surface area, total pore volume and pore diameter of the catalysts were listed in Table 1 . It was worth noting that Mn-AC catalyst exhibited a relatively higher specific surface area and pore volume compared to Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts. This difference might be associated with the particular spherical morphology of Mn-AC catalyst. The specific surface area and pore volume were the crucial parameters that contributed to the availability of reaction channels and surface active sites on the catalyst surface, thus enhancing the catalytic performance for NO reduction and CO oxidation [28,29]. According to the catalytic activity as depicted in Section 3.2, it could be concluded that the higher specific surface area and total pore volume were related to the superior catalytic activity of the catalysts. The morphologies of Mn-AC, Mn-SH, and Mn-AH catalysts were characterized using SEM analysis, as depicted in Fig. 3 . Mn-AC catalyst presented a spherical morphology with a relatively large particle size. In contrast, Mn-SH catalyst predominantly comprised the octahedral structure along with numerous fragmented small particles. And Mn-AH catalyst maintained an irregular cube shape with smaller sizes and exhibited a relatively smooth surface. These results demonstrated the choice of different precipitants could significantly influence the morphology of catalysts, even when they possessed the same chemical composition. 3.2 Catalytic performance of bifunctional MnO x catalysts The catalytic performance of bifunctional MnO x catalysts for the simultaneous removal of NO and CO was evaluated, and the results were shown in Fig. 4 . As depicted in Fig. 4(a), all the catalytic activity curves exhibited a characteristic volcano shape, with an initial increase followed by a subsequent decrease as a function of temperature. Notably, Mn-AC catalyst displayed superior SCR catalytic activity over the entire temperature range, achieving a remarkable conversion rate of 89% at 100 ºC. Conversely, both Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts displayed poor catalytic activity, of which, Mn-AH catalyst exhibited only a modest NO conversion rate of 25.4% at 100 ºC. Additionally, this study also evaluated the N2 selectivity, N2O production, NO2 concentration and NH3 conversion for the catalysts, as displayed in Fig. S1. It can be seen that the N2 selectivity of Mn-AC catalyst was higher than that of Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts. Moreover, the NH3 conversion of all catalysts followed the same trend as the catalytic activity of NO reduction. Fig. 4(b) illustrated the catalytic activity of bifunctional MnO x catalysts for CO catalytic oxidation. Clearly, the CO conversion of all catalysts displayed a similar trend, showing an upward trend as the reaction temperature increased. The catalyst synthesized with ammonium carbonate exhibited excellent CO catalytic oxidation activity compared to the catalysts prepared with sodium hydroxide and ammonium hydroxide as precipitants. Specifically, Mn-AC catalyst achieved 80% conversion of CO at 200 ºC, while Mn-AH catalyst only attained a modest 8% CO conversion rate at the same temperature. These results suggested that Mn-AC catalyst displayed superior catalytic activity in both NO reduction and CO oxidation. However, the specific interplay between NH3-SCR reaction and CO catalytic oxidation remains unclear. Consequently, the separate and coordinate experiments for NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation reactions were performed. Given the excellent catalytic activity of Mn-AC catalyst in the simultaneous elimination of both NO and CO, it was selected as a representative sample for further analysis. The synergistic reaction performance of NH3-SCR and CO oxidation over Mn-AC catalyst was also comparatively investigated for the separate NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation, as depicted in Fig. 5 . As shown in Fig. 5(a), the separate NH3-SCR reaction on Mn-AC catalyst demonstrated that NO conversion rate of about 83% at 100 ºC. However, for the synergistic reaction of NH3-SCR and CO oxidation, the NO conversion rate exceeded 90% at the same temperature, suggesting that the addition of CO in the NH3-SCR reaction facilitated NO reduction. And it was consistent with the previous studies [30,31]. Zeng et al. [30] observed that the heat released by CO oxidation could significantly enhance the temperature of flue gas, thus enhanced the NO conversion in the NH3-SCR reaction. Guo et al. [31] indicated that NO conversion could be enhanced by CO introduction at lower temperature, since NO could be adsorbed on the CO pre-adsorbed sites for the reduction of NO to N2. However, it could be seen that CO conversion in the coordinate NO reduction and CO catalytic oxidation between 100 and 150 ºC was lower than that observed in the separate CO catalytic oxidation, and this disparity might be ascribed to the competitive adsorption between the reaction gasses. Nevertheless, it could be seen that CO conversion in the coordinate CO catalytic oxidation between 100 and 150 ºC was lower than that in the separate CO catalytic oxidation, and the decline might be related to the competitive adsorption between CO and other reactants [32]. 3.3 Surface composition analysis XPS analysis was employed to probe into the elemental oxidation valence state and the relative proportions of various valences states over all catalysts, and the spectra were presented in Fig. 6 . In Fig. 6(a), the Mn 2p3/2 spectrum could be fitted well into three characteristic peaks, corresponding to Mn2+ (640.8 eV), Mn3+ (642.0 eV), and Mn4+ (643.4 eV) species, respectively [33]. The integrated areas of the split peaks suggested that the majority of Mn species on the catalysts existed in the Mn3+ species, accompanied by a smaller proportion of Mn2+ and Mn4+ species. Numerous studies indicated that a high relative proportion of Mn4+/(Mn4++Mn3++Mn2+) was more likely to form active oxygen species to balance the chemical states and stabilize the structures [34–36]. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the O 1s spectrum displayed two distinct peaks. The peak at around 529.1–529.3 eV was attributed to the lattice oxygen species (Oα), while the peak at around 530.9–531.2 eV was assigned to the chemisorbed oxygen species (Oβ) [37]. The chemisorbed oxygen species with higher mobility exhibited higher activity than lattice oxygen Oα and played a crucial role in the catalytic activity [38]. Specifically, Mn4+ and Oβ species favored the excellent redox property of the catalysts, and they could also be served as the active sites for the reaction, facilitating the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO at lower temperature, thereby enhancing the low-temperature SCR activity [7,39]. Table 2 presented that the relative proportions of Mn4+ and Oβ species over Mn-AC catalyst were the highest among all catalysts. And the orders of Oβ/Ototal and Mn4+/Mntotal of the catalysts were consistent with the observed catalytic activities for NH3-SCR reaction. 3.4 Redox property and surface acidity The H2-TPR and the NH3-TPD characterizations were utilized to identify the reducibility and surface acidity of the catalysts, and the results were illustrated in Fig. 7 . As presented in Fig. 7(a), all samples displayed two different reduction stages within the temperature range of 100–700 ºC, labeled as peak Ι and peak Ⅱ, respectively. It was reported that the peak around 250 ºC was assigned to the reduction of active oxygen species [40,41], the peak at approximately around 410 ºC was attributed to the transformation of Mn4+ to Mn3+ [42], and the peak above 700 ºC was associated with the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ [43]. For Mn-AC catalyst, two reduction peaks were observed at 279 and 409 ºC, corresponding to the reduction of surface oxygen species and the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+, respectively, which was consistent with the previous study by Shi et al. [44]. Similarly, Mn-SH catalyst exhibited two reduction peaks, with the peak at 371 ºC was attributed to the reduction of the nonstoichiometric excess oxygen species in the lattice and Mn4+ species, and the peak at 503 ºC associated with the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+. Likewise, Mn-AH catalyst showed two peaks at 320 and 475 ºC, indicating the removal of the nonstoichiometric excess oxygen species in the lattice and the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+, respectively [45]. Nevertheless, it could be observed that the reduction temperature of reducible species on Mn-AC catalyst surface was lower than that of other catalysts, which might be related to the abundant surface oxygen and Mn4+ species. It has been reported that the superior redox properties at low temperature contributed to improve the low-temperature activity of the catalysts [46]. Additionally, the H2 consumption of catalysts was estimated based on the peak area obtained from the H2-TPR profile, as illustrated in Fig. S2. It was clear that all catalysts possessed different H2 consumption, corresponding to their distinct reduction behavior. Fig. 7(b) revealed that all samples showed one desorption peak between 100 and 700 ºC. Previous literatures reported the desorption peak above 400 ºC was assigned to NH3 species on medium and strong acid sites [47,48]. In general, the acid amount could be represented by the area of the desorption peak. The acid amount sequence was as follows: Mn-AC > Mn-SH > Mn-AH, which indicated that Mn-AC catalyst possessed stronger surface acidity. The adsorption and activation of NH3 species were facilitated by stronger surface acidity, which exhibited the potential to enhance the SCR catalytic activity [49]. The consistency between the surface acidity of all catalysts and their denitrification activity suggested that surface acidity might be an important factor in the NO reduction process. The type of acid sites and the evolving situation of adsorbed NH3 species with temperature on catalysts surface were investigated by in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption and desorption experiments, and the results were presented in Fig. 8 . Upon introducing NH3 at 50 ºC, the bands in the range of 1000–1800 cm−1 emerged and exhibited a gradual increase trend over time. For Mn-AC catalyst shown in Fig. 8(a), the bands at 1195 and 1612 cm−1 were assigned to NH3 coordinated to the Lewis (L) acid sites, the band at 1528 cm−1 was attributed to NH2 species, and the bands at 1528 and 1693 cm−1 were ascribed to the NH4 +species on Brønsted (B) acid sites [50,51]. Similarly, for Mn-SH catalyst, the band at 1343 cm−1 was assigned to NH3 coordinated to L acid sites, while the band at 1625 cm−1 was linked to the NH4 +species on B acid sites [52]. For Mn-AH catalyst, three bands were observed, including the bands at 1520 and 1693 cm−1 corresponded to NH3 coordinated to L acid sites, and the band at 1635 cm−1 associated with the NH4 +species on B acid sites [53,54]. It was evident that the intensity of NH3 adsorption bands on Mn-AC catalyst was stronger than those on Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts, suggesting a higher total amount of the B acid and L acid sites on Mn-AC catalyst, as also confirmed by the NH3-TPD analysis. Furthermore, in situ DRIFTS of NH3 desorption spectra were obtained during the heating process to investigate the thermal stability and behavior of NH3 adsorption on the catalysts. It could be seen that the band intensities of L acid and B acid sites on the catalysts decreased with the increase of temperature, but the band at 1528 cm−1 (NH2 species) still existed on the Mn-AC catalyst surface at 300 ºC, suggesting that some adsorbed NH3 species were oxidized to the NH2 on Mn-AC catalyst. 3.5 In situ DRIFTS study of NO + O2/CO adsorption and desorption To gain a thorough understanding of the adsorption and desorption characteristics of surface adsorbed species, in situ DRIFTS of NO + O2/CO adsorption and desorption experiments were performed on bifunctional MnO x catalysts synthesized using different precipitants. In situ DRIFTS spectra of NO + O2 adsorption and desorption on Mn-AC, Mn-SH, and Mn-AH catalysts were recorded, and displayed in Fig. 9 . For Mn-AC catalyst, two bands appeared at approximately 1319 and 1369 cm−1, and their intensities exhibited the time-dependent increase. Specifically, the band at 1319 cm−1 was attributed to bidentate nitrite, while the band at 1369 cm−1 was assigned to the monodentate nitrite [55,56]. Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts exhibited a single band corresponding to monodentate nitrite at 1369 cm−1. It could be seen that the intensity of the bands decreased as the temperature increased from 50 to 200 ºC, indicating the desorption and decomposition of adsorbed species during the heating process. When the temperature reached 200 ºC, a transformation from monodentate nitrite to bridged nitrates was observed over all catalysts. Moreover, it was worth noting that Mn-AC catalyst displayed higher band intensities compared to other catalysts during both the adsorption and desorption processes, indicating its excellent NO adsorption properties. In situ DRIFTS of CO adsorption and desorption on bifunctional MnO x catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 10 . For Mn-AC and Mn-AH catalysts, two bands were observed at 1627 and 2341 cm−1, with the band at 1627 cm−1 was ascribed to bidentate carbonate [57], and the band at 2341 cm−1 was assigned to the gaseous CO2 [58]. The Mn-SH catalyst exhibited three bands at 1539, 1627, and 2341 cm−1, which corresponded to the carboxylate, bidentate carbonate, and gaseous CO2, respectively [59,60]. Importantly, the prominent species observed on Mn-AC catalyst was the bidentate carbonate species at 1627 cm−1. In general, the bands at 1200–1700 cm−1 mainly represented carboxylate and bidentate carbonate that originated from the reduction of surface adsorbed oxygen and Mn4+ species. The reduction of high-valence Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Mn2+ by CO resulted in the oxidization of CO to CO2. The Mn-AC catalyst displayed a stronger adsorption capacity for CO as bidentate carbonate compared to Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts, which confirmed that the superior catalytic performance of Mn-AC catalyst for CO oxidation in the whole temperature range. The interaction mechanism between NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation reactions over Mn-AC catalyst was further elucidated through in situ DRIFTS analysis, as shown in Fig. 11 . After the adsorption of NO + O2 at 175 ºC, the bands of linear nitrite (1336 cm−1) and monodentate nitrite (1515 cm−1) emerged. It could be observed that the pre-adsorption of NH3 and CO had a significant effect on the adsorption bands intensity on Mn-AC catalyst. Specifically, upon pre-adsorption of NH3 before the introduction of NO + O2, an obvious decrease in the intensity of DRIFTS spectra was observed in comparison to the adsorption of NO + O2. In contrast, pre-adsorption of CO before introducing NO + O2 led to an increased intensity of the spectra compared to NO + O2 adsorption. In addition, the band corresponding to NO2 species at 1635 cm−1 was found on the DRIFTS spectra of CO pre-adsorbed + NO +O2. The results indicated that the presence of CO facilitated the adsorption and activation of NO. Our previous study indicated that the adsorbed nitrite species could react with NH4 + species to form NH4NO3. Then NH4NO3 could react with absorbed NO to generate N2 and H2O [22]. Moreover, Long et al. [61] proposed a mechanism that one NO2 molecule could react with two adjacent NH4 + to form intermediate NO2[NH4 +]2, then the intermediate could react with NO to produce N2 and H2O. The production of NO2 was considered as the key intermediate species for the occurrence of “Fast SCR” reaction. And the results were confirmed by the excellent catalytic performance of the synergistic reaction of NH3-SCR and CO oxidation experiments. 3.5 Mechanism discussion Bifunctional MnO x catalysts were synthesized by utilizing ammonium carbonate, sodium hydroxide, and ammonium hydroxide as precipitants, and these resulting catalysts were composed of a mixture of different phases. Specifically, Mn-AC catalyst exhibited a combination of Mn3O4 and MnO2 phases, whereas Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts displayed the mixed phases of Mn3O4 and Mn5O8 Fig. 1). Mn-AC catalyst displayed a spherical morphology with a relatively large size while Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts were composed of cubic nanoparticles with smaller sizes (Fig. 3). From Fig. 4, the catalytic performance for both NO reduction and CO oxidation of the catalysts followed the order of Mn-AC > Mn-AH > Mn-SH catalysts. Through a series of characterizations and in situ DRIFT experiments, the schematic diagram of three precipitants over bifunctional MnO x catalysts was presented in Fig. 12 . Despite all catalysts contained the identical proportion of active components, the choice of precipitants did make a change for the catalytic performance and physicochemical property of the catalysts, primarily by influencing the distribution of surface-active sites on the catalysts [62]. NH3-TPD test confirmed that Mn-AC catalyst possessed excellent surface acidity and defined the nature of acid sites on all catalysts (from Fig. 7(b)). XPS analysis was employed to explore the chemical state of active species. More abundant Mn4+ and chemisorbed oxygen species were contributed to the excellent low-temperature redox property of Mn-AC catalyst [18]. In situ DRIFTS of NH3/NO+O2/CO adsorption and desorption experiments were used to elaborate the adsorption, activation, and transformation behaviors of reactants over the catalysts. For NH3 adsorption (Eqs. (4)-((6)), it could be found that the precipitants might affect the acid sites on the catalysts surface, and Mn-AC catalyst possessed more B acid and L acid sites (from Fig. 8). Abundant acid sites were contributed to the improvement of NH3 adsorption ability of the catalysts, resulting in the excellent SCR catalytic activity. Regarding to the NO+O2 co-adsorption Eqs. (7)-((10)), it was observed that Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts exhibited less variety of nitrate species (from Fig. 9). However, the NO3 − species could react with NH4 + species to form NH4NO3 Eq. (11)). And NH4NO3 could react with the absorbed NO to generate N2 and H2O (Eq. (12)) [22]. For CO catalytic oxidation, the reduction of high-valence Mn4+ to Mn3+ by CO resulted in the oxidization of CO to CO2 (Eqs. (13)-(15)). Mn-AC catalyst possessed more high-valence Mn4+ species and stronger adsorption capacity for CO than Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts (seeing Fig. 10). Additionally, in situ DRIFTS spectra of NO + O2 co-adsorption after CO adsorption indicated that the pre-desorption of CO facilitated the adsorption and activation of NO (from Fig. 11). The production of adsorbed NO2 species at 1635 cm−1 was beneficial for enhancing the low-temperature SCR activity, because NO2 was identified as a potential oxidizer in the “Fast SCR” reaction [43,63]. (4) N H 3 ( g ) → L acid sites N H 3 ( ads ) (5) N H 3 ( g ) + M n 4 + + O ( a ) → L acid sites M n 3 + + N H 2 ( ads ) + OH (6) N H 3 ( g ) + H + → B acid sites NH 4 + ( ads ) (7) NO ( g ) + O ( a ) → N O 2 ( ads ) (8) M n 3 + + O ( a ) → M n 4 + − O (9) M n 3 + + N O 2 ( ads ) → M n 4 + + NO 2 − (10) M n 4 + − O + N O 2 ( ads ) → M n 4 + + NO 3 − (11) NO 3 − + NH 4 + ( ads ) → N H 4 N O 3 (12) N H 4 N O 3 + NO ( ads ) → N O 2 + N 2 + H 2 O (13) CO ( g ) → CO ( ads ) (14) CO ( ads ) + M n 4 + → M n 3 + + C O + (15) C O + + O − → C O 2 + O v 4 Conclusion In this study, bifunctional catalysts were synthesized using different precipitants to investigate the influence of precipitants on the catalytic performance for both NO reduction and CO oxidation in detail. The results of SEM and XRD analysis revealed that the choice of precipitants played a decisive role in shaping the morphology and crystalline phase of the synthesized catalysts. When AC was used as the precipitant, the catalyst consisted mainly of MnO2 and Mn3O4 with a spherical morphology. Using SH and AH as the precipitates resulted in the catalysts composing predominantly of Mn3O4 and Mn5O8 with polyhedron shapes. The catalytic activity tests demonstrated that Mn-AC catalyst presented higher catalytic activity for both NO reduction and CO oxidation compared to Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts. The excellent catalytic activity of Mn-AC catalyst could be attributed to the higher specific surface area, larger pore volume, abundant Mn4+ and Oβ species, and stronger surface acidity. In situ DRIFTS result indicated that stronger adsorption and activation capacity of catalyst to the reactant played a crucial role in enhancing the catalytic activity for NH3-SCR reaction and CO catalytic oxidation. coredata.dc:description: In this work, ammonium carbonate, sodium hydroxide, and ammonium hydroxide were selected as the precipitants to prepare bifunctional MnO x catalysts via the PEG-assisted co-precipitation method. SEM analysis revealed that MnO x catalysts prepared with ammonium carbonate (AC) displayed a spherical morphology with relatively large size, whereas the catalysts synthesized with sodium hydroxide (SH) and ammonium hydroxide (AH) exhibited polyhedron shapes with smaller size. The results demonstrated that Mn-AC catalyst presented superior catalytic activity for both NO reduction and CO oxidation, achieving 89% NO conversion at 100 ºC and over 80% CO conversion at 200 ºC, outperforming Mn-SH and Mn-AH catalysts. Mn-AC catalyst possessed more abundant Mn4+ species and surface chemisorbed oxygen than Mn-AH and Mn-SH catalysts, which served as a significant motivation for the difference in catalytic activity. Additionally, Mn-AC catalyst exhibited stronger surface acidity, which facilitated the adsorption and activation of ammonia species in the NH3-SCR reaction. Furthermore, in situ DRIFTS experiment suggested that the pre-desorption of CO promoted the adsorption and activation of NO. On this basis, the possible mechanism model of three precipitants on bifunctional MnO x catalysts was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: A comparison of bifunctional MnO x catalysts prepared via different precipitants for simultaneous removal NO and CO
